Get up to date info from NWS (National Weather Service)  Weather forecasting is a side note here. Its also where FOX gets their info from. And since NWS updates hourly or more, you will get today's info, not yesterday evenings. And the GFS model has it moving up the west side of Florida starting early Tuesday morning. Landfall looks to be more north now, eastern panhandle area.  Will the west coast of Fla get some flooding from storm surge? Yes.  Its the west coast of Florida, and anytime a storm moves up that side it will happen.  And understand that NOBODY can see the future. So just be prepared ahead of time, and get on with living.

context: I live in SW Florida. We need to pay attention to hurricanes. However, local news going to Home Depot etc to ask shoppers if they are getting ready for Elsa, 5 days before expected landfall, is over the top. Already had newbies for the northeast ask if they should evacuate.

replies.context: Yea they should

When my mom lived on Ft Myers Beach, until she passed at 99, she was ready all year long.  She knew to have everything ready, including Rx, batteries etc, BEFORE June 1.  She lived there with my dad until he died and then another 20+ years and never was caught unprepared.  The newbies need to have it hammered into their pea brains until they understand the seriousness of hurricanes.
I would have told them yes it is a good time to evacuate but please don't come back....

We're in SE FL and here the philosophy is that it's never too early to prepare. Necessary items like water, batteries, etc. are in short supply, if available at all, days before a possible landfall. It's happened to us so I'm talking from personal experience. Been here forever and didn't hesitate to run out yesterday to top off my supplies.

Agree. My point was being prepared for loss of power is a year round thing, not just hurricane season. People everywhere should be prepared for loss of power, whether it's from weather, fire, accidents etc.

5 days before is the BEST TIME TO GET READY.  You idiots that wait are just plain stupid.  But truck will be fully fueled up today, my property cleaned up and ready for the wind, and I am south of Daytona on the coast.  And yes I am monitoring it and I will evacuate very early if it comes here, and it is trending more east in the models after the 8 AM updates.  If it does not come here my truck will be fine with a full tank and my yard will be cleaner.  I have ridden out several hurricanes, will never do it again, the storm is cool, but that living with no AC after and no stores open is misserable, why bother when I can go to the NC mountains and enjoy.  But everyone in Florida should be getting ready today.

I have spent my entire life in Florida, primarily in the Florida keys and SW Florida. Don’t under estimate a Hurricane whether it’s a Cat.1 or Cat.5. Your life depends on it. Prepare now for the season, this won’t be the last one.
I’m in the Keys now. We just mull it over some rum while staring at the boxes of supplies left from Irma. Bring it on!
You’re right! They always hype up these storms too much. This one looks weak, and it might not even track into Florida.

context: I am a northeast transplant who will spend the majority of my remaining years in Southwest Florida. My intention is to enjoy the sunshine, fishing, and beach relaxation. I certainly have no intention of ruffling the feathers of the locals, but rather assimilate into the culture, as best as I can. I can say, that certainly, we from the northeast, are overly concerned for reports of hurricanes anywhere they make landfall. But this reaction is the result of years of devastating news coverage, where the news outlets in the Northeast sensationalize, for little more than improving their ratings, every tropical storm event that develops. For this reason alone, I suppose that we are very cautious when these storms are about to impact our lives.
